name: Table
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table
description:
Table

A named resource representing a BigQuery table that holds zero or more records. Every table is defined by a schema that may contain nested and repeated fields.

examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
bigquery = gcloud.bigquery
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"

table = dataset.create_table "my_table" do |schema|
  schema.string "first_name", mode: :required
  schema.record "cities_lived", mode: :repeated do |nested_schema|
    nested_schema.string "place", mode: :required
    nested_schema.integer "number_of_years", mode: :required
  end
end

row = {
  "first_name" => "Alice",
  "cities_lived" => [
    {
      "place" => "Seattle",
      "number_of_years" => 5
    },
    {
      "place" => "Stockholm",
      "number_of_years" => 6
    }
  ]
}
table.insert row

methods.name: table_id
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#table_id
methods.description: A unique ID for this table. The ID must contain only letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9), or underscores (_). The maximum length is 1,024 characters.

methods.name: dataset_id
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#dataset_id
methods.description: The ID of the Dataset containing this table.

methods.name: project_id
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#project_id
methods.description: The ID of the Project containing this table.

methods.name: id
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#id
methods.description: The combined Project ID, Dataset ID, and Table ID for this table, in the format specified by the Query Reference: project_name:datasetId.tableId. To use this value in queries see #query_id.

methods.name: query_id
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#query_id
methods.description: The value returned by #id, wrapped in square brackets if the Project ID contains dashes, as specified by the Query Reference. Useful in queries.

examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
bigquery = gcloud.bigquery
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

data = bigquery.query "SELECT name FROM #{table.query_id}"

methods.name: name
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#name
methods.description: The name of the table.

methods.name: name=
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#name=
methods.description: Updates the name of the table.

methods.name: etag
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#etag
methods.description: A string hash of the dataset.

methods.name: api_url
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#api_url
methods.description: A URL that can be used to access the dataset using the REST API.

methods.name: description
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#description
methods.description: The description of the table.

methods.name: description=
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#description=
methods.description: Updates the description of the table.

methods.name: bytes_count
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#bytes_count
methods.description: The number of bytes in the table.

methods.name: rows_count
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#rows_count
methods.description: The number of rows in the table.

methods.name: created_at
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#created_at
methods.description: The time when this table was created.

methods.name: expires_at
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#expires_at
methods.description: The time when this table expires. If not present, the table will persist indefinitely. Expired tables will be deleted and their storage reclaimed.

methods.name: modified_at
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#modified_at
methods.description: The date when this table was last modified.

methods.name: table?
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#table?
methods.description: Checks if the table’s type is “TABLE”.

methods.name: view?
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#view?
methods.description: Checks if the table’s type is “VIEW”.

methods.name: location
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#location
methods.description: The geographic location where the table should reside. Possible values include EU and US. The default value is US.

methods.name: schema
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#schema
methods.description: Returns the table’s schema as hash containing the keys and values returned by the Google Cloud BigQuery Rest API . This method can also be used to set, replace, or add to the schema by passing a block. See Schema for available methods.

examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
bigquery = gcloud.bigquery
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.create_table "my_table"

table.schema do |schema|
  schema.string "first_name", mode: :required
  schema.record "cities_lived", mode: :repeated do |nested_schema|
    nested_schema.string "place", mode: :required
    nested_schema.integer "number_of_years", mode: :required
  end
end

params.name: replace
params.description: Whether to replace the existing schema with the new schema. If true, the fields will replace the existing schema. If false, the fields will be added to the existing schema. When a table already contains data, schema changes must be additive. Thus, the default value is false.

params.name: yield
params.description: a block for setting the schema

params.name: yield.schema
params.description: the object accepting the schema

methods.name: fields
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#fields
methods.description: The fields of the table.

methods.name: headers
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#headers
methods.description: The names of the columns in the table.

methods.name: data
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#data
methods.description: Retrieves data from the table.

examples.caption: Paginate rows of data: (See Data#next)
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
bigquery = gcloud.bigquery
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

data = table.data
data.each do |row|
  puts row["first_name"]
end
if data.next?
  more_data = data.next if data.next?
end

examples.caption: Retrieve all rows of data: (See Data#all)
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
bigquery = gcloud.bigquery
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

data = table.data
data.all do |row|
  puts row["first_name"]
end

params.name: token
params.description:
Page token, returned by a previous call,
identifying the result set.

params.name: max
params.description: Maximum number of results to return.

params.name: start
params.description: Zero-based index of the starting row to read.

methods.name: copy
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#copy
methods.description: Copies the data from the table to another table. The destination table argument can also be a string identifier as specified by the Query Reference: project_name:datasetId.tableId. This is useful for referencing tables in other projects and datasets.

examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
bigquery = gcloud.bigquery
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"
destination_table = dataset.table "my_destination_table"

copy_job = table.copy destination_table

examples.caption: Passing a string identifier for the destination table:
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
bigquery = gcloud.bigquery
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

copy_job = table.copy "other-project:other_dataset.other_table"

params.name: destination_table
params.description:
The destination for the copied
data.

params.name: create
params.description:
Specifies whether the job is allowed to create new tables.

The following values are supported:

  • needed - Create the table if it does not exist.
  • never - The table must already exist. A ‘notFound’ error is raised if the table does not exist.

params.name: write
params.description:
Specifies how to handle data already present in the destination table. The default value is empty.

The following values are supported:

  • truncate - BigQuery overwrites the table data.
  • append - BigQuery appends the data to the table.
  • empty - An error will be returned if the destination table already contains data.

methods.name: extract
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#extract
methods.description: Extract the data from the table to a Google Cloud Storage file.

examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
bigquery = gcloud.bigquery
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

extract_job = table.extract "gs://my-bucket/file-name.json",
                            format: "json"

params.name: extract_url
params.description:
The
Google Storage file or file URI pattern(s) to which BigQuery should
extract the table data.

params.name: format
params.description:
The exported file format. The default value is csv.

The following values are supported:

  • csv - CSV
  • json - Newline-delimited JSON
  • avro - Avro

params.name: compression
params.description: The compression type to use for exported files. Possible values include GZIP and NONE. The default value is NONE.

params.name: delimiter
params.description: Delimiter to use between fields in the exported data. Default is ,.

params.name: header
params.description: Whether to print out a header row in the results. Default is true.

methods.name: load
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#load
methods.description:
Loads data into the table. You can pass a gcloud-ruby storage file path or a gcloud-ruby storage file instance. Or, you can upload a file directly. See Loading Data with a POST Request.

A chunk_size value can be provided in the options to be used in resumable uploads. This value is the number of bytes per chunk and must be divisible by 256KB. If it is not divisible by 256KB then it will be lowered to the nearest acceptable value.

A note about large direct uploads

You may encounter a Broken pipe (Errno::EPIPE) error when attempting to upload large files. To avoid this problem, add the httpclient gem to your project, and the line (or lines) of configuration shown below. These lines must execute after require "gcloud" but before you make your first connection. The first statement configures Faraday to use httpclient. The second statement, which should only be added if you are using a version of Faraday at or above 0.9.2, is a workaround for this gzip issue.

examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
bigquery = gcloud.bigquery
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

load_job = table.load "gs://my-bucket/file-name.csv"

examples.caption: Pass a gcloud-ruby storage file instance:
examples.code:
require "gcloud"
require "gcloud/storage"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
bigquery = gcloud.bigquery
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

storage = gcloud.storage
bucket = storage.bucket "my-bucket"
file = bucket.file "file-name.csv"
load_job = table.load file

examples.caption: Upload a file directly:
examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
bigquery = gcloud.bigquery
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

file = File.open "my_data.csv"
load_job = table.load file

require "gcloud"

# Use httpclient to avoid broken pipe errors with large uploads
Faraday.default_adapter = :httpclient

# Only add the following statement if using Faraday >= 0.9.2
# Override gzip middleware with no-op for httpclient
Faraday::Response.register_middleware :gzip =>
                                        Faraday::Response::Middleware

gcloud = Gcloud.new
bigquery = gcloud.bigquery

params.name: file
params.description:
A file or the URI of a
Google Cloud Storage file containing data to load into the table.

params.name: format
params.description:
The exported file format. The default value is csv.

The following values are supported:

  • csv - CSV
  • json - Newline-delimited JSON
  • avro - Avro
  • datastore_backup - Cloud Datastore backup

params.name: create
params.description:
Specifies whether the job is allowed to create new tables.

The following values are supported:

  • needed - Create the table if it does not exist.
  • never - The table must already exist. A ‘notFound’ error is raised if the table does not exist.

params.name: write
params.description:
Specifies how to handle data already present in the table. The default value is empty.

The following values are supported:

  • truncate - BigQuery overwrites the table data.
  • append - BigQuery appends the data to the table.
  • empty - An error will be returned if the table already contains data.

params.name: projection_fields
params.description: If the format option is set to datastore_backup, indicates which entity properties to load from a Cloud Datastore backup. Property names are case sensitive and must be top-level properties. If not set, BigQuery loads all properties. If any named property isn’t found in the Cloud Datastore backup, an invalid error is returned.

params.name: jagged_rows
params.description: Accept rows that are missing trailing optional columns. The missing values are treated as nulls. If false, records with missing trailing columns are treated as bad records, and if there are too many bad records, an invalid error is returned in the job result. The default value is false. Only applicable to CSV, ignored for other formats.

params.name: quoted_newlines
params.description: Indicates if BigQuery should allow quoted data sections that contain newline characters in a CSV file. The default value is false.

params.name: encoding
params.description: The character encoding of the data. The supported values are UTF-8 or ISO-8859-1. The default value is UTF-8.

params.name: delimiter
params.description: Specifices the separator for fields in a CSV file. BigQuery converts the string to ISO-8859-1 encoding, and then uses the first byte of the encoded string to split the data in its raw, binary state. Default is ,.

params.name: ignore_unknown
params.description:
Indicates if BigQuery should allow extra values that are not represented in the table schema. If true, the extra values are ignored. If false, records with extra columns are treated as bad records, and if there are too many bad records, an invalid error is returned in the job result. The default value is false.

The format property determines what BigQuery treats as an extra value:

  • CSV: Trailing columns
  • JSON: Named values that don’t match any column names

params.name: max_bad_records
params.description: The maximum number of bad records that BigQuery can ignore when running the job. If the number of bad records exceeds this value, an invalid error is returned in the job result. The default value is 0, which requires that all records are valid.

params.name: quote
params.description: The value that is used to quote data sections in a CSV file. BigQuery converts the string to ISO-8859-1 encoding, and then uses the first byte of the encoded string to split the data in its raw, binary state. The default value is a double-quote ". If your data does not contain quoted sections, set the property value to an empty string. If your data contains quoted newline characters, you must also set the allowQuotedNewlines property to true.

params.name: skip_leading
params.description: The number of rows at the top of a CSV file that BigQuery will skip when loading the data. The default value is 0. This property is useful if you have header rows in the file that should be skipped.

methods.name: insert
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#insert
methods.description: Inserts data into the table for near-immediate querying, without the need to complete a #load operation before the data can appear in query results.

examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
bigquery = gcloud.bigquery
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

rows = [
  { "first_name" => "Alice", "age" => 21 },
  { "first_name" => "Bob", "age" => 22 }
]
table.insert rows

params.name: rows
params.description:
A hash object or array of hash objects
containing the data.

params.name: skip_invalid
params.description: Insert all valid rows of a request, even if invalid rows exist. The default value is false, which causes the entire request to fail if any invalid rows exist.

params.name: ignore_unknown
params.description:
Accept rows that contain values that do
not match the schema. The unknown values are ignored. Default is
false, which treats unknown values as errors.

methods.name: delete
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#delete
methods.description: Permanently deletes the table.

examples.code:
require "gcloud"

gcloud = Gcloud.new
bigquery = gcloud.bigquery
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

table.delete

returns.description: Returns true if the table was deleted.

methods.name: reload!
title: Gcloud
Bigquery
Table#reload!
methods.description: Reloads the table with current data from the BigQuery service.
